pr_title: Metadata identifier for Communities and Collections

timeline.message:
[CSTPER-221] Integration Test

The creation of communities (toplevel and subcommunities) and the
creation of collections implies population of dc.identifier.uri
metatada.
We also prove that the logic doesn't affect the creation of other types
of entities (eperson).
[CSTPER-221] CommunityRestRepository common code refactoring
[CSTPER-221] Handle Providers enhanced for Communities and Collections
[CSTPER-221] DOI Collection/Community exclusion
[CSTPER-221] RestMetadata applied without deleting existing ones.
[CSTPER-221] Tests refined
[CSTPER-221] Reverted modifications to the register method
[CSTPER-221] Versioned handle populate metadata cleanup
[CSTPER-221] EZIDIdentifierProvider exclusions
[CSTPER-221] Validation check and MetadataConverter merge facility
[CSTPER-221] EZIDIdentifierProvider exclusions
[CSTPER-221] Minor changes and cleanup
[CSTPER-221] MetadataConverter fixed

[CSTPER-221] Fixed Authorization denied during subCommunity creation

We need to persist the newCommunity before adding the handle metadata
value. The failing test was
* CommunityRestRepositoryIT.createSubCommunityAuthorizedTest

[CSTPER-221] Script Flyway to populate handle metadata

For existing Collection/Community
[CSTPER-221] Collection handle generation after creation
[CSTPER-221] Fixed Unit tests

[CSTPER-221] Script Flyway to populate handle metadata

Fixed Javadoc.

timeline.bodyText:
Have we fully tested this SQL_INSERT on Postgres and Oracle?  I'm a little nervous about hardcoding this SQL as a string in Java, simply because it means we cannot easily customize it for Postgres vs Oracle as necessary.
Normally, the process is to provide separate *.sql files under dspace-api/src/main/resources/org/dspace/storage/rdbms/sqlmigration/[db-type]/, rather than hardcoding SQL into Java.
If this has not been tested on Oracle, I'd prefer we replace this logic with SQL files, even though I realize that'd require having two INSERT statements in each file (one for community & one for collection)
timeline.author: tdonohue

replies.bodyText: We discussed a lot about it with @abollini. We option for a fully java based script since we have to make aware the database of the prefix value from configuration. This means we will still need a Java based script to properly initialize sql. Having said that in my opinion there is no problem in moving the sql part into separate files (and replicating it twice each).
replies.author: alemarte

replies.bodyText:
@alemarte : To clarify, my concern here is that hardcoding SQL into Java means that the SQL must work on all database types.  So, again, I'm wondering if this SQL has been tested on Oracle?  If we can prove it works for both Postgres & Oracle, then this approach is OK.  Otherwise, we must refactor this to use SQL scripts that are database type specific, as that allows us to customize the SQL per database type.
I'm a little nervous that this hardcoded SQL may not be cross-database compatible (as it's quite complex), but I hope I'm wrong.  In any case, I'd appreciate it if you could test this on Oracle to ensure it'll work there as well.  If so, then it's fine as-is.  If not, then we need to figure out a different solution that allows the Oracle SQL and Postgres SQL to be different.   One option might be to move to SQL files and use Flyway Placeholders (https://flywaydb.org/documentation/configuration/placeholder) in the SQL to represent the prefix -- but I'm not sure how easy that'd be, as we've not had to use placeholders yet in any other migration.
replies.author: tdonohue
alemarte

timeline.bodyText: You can remove this logic, as there's no need to reset Configuration values.  They automatically reset after every test.  So, the try/finally can be removed & the getProperty at the top.   Just call setProperty to change the value, and it'll reset automatically.
timeline.author: tdonohue

replies.bodyText: At a first glance, I haven't found anything like a configuration reset. This maybe happens only for IntegrationTests?
replies.author: alemarte
tdonohue

timeline.bodyText: Again, remove this logic...configs reset automatically
timeline.author: tdonohue

timeline.message:
[CSTPER-221] Script Flyway to populate handle metadata

Moved to sql files.

timeline.author: tdonohue

timeline.bodyText:
If you go with the approach I suggested above, I think this line (and the same line in the other INSERT statement) would just become:
concat("${handle.canonical.prefix}", h.handle) as text_value,

Obviously, you can also remove other references to the T2 table in this script (namely the cross join below)
timeline.author: tdonohue
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,99 @@
+--
+-- The contents of this file are subject to the license and copyright
+-- detailed in the LICENSE and NOTICE files at the root of the source
+-- tree and available online at
+--
+-- http://www.dspace.org/license/
+--
+
+-- ===============================================================
+-- WARNING WARNING WARNING WARNING WARNING WARNING WARNING WARNING
+--
+-- DO NOT MANUALLY RUN THIS DATABASE MIGRATION. IT WILL BE EXECUTED
+-- AUTOMATICALLY (IF NEEDED) BY "FLYWAY" WHEN YOU STARTUP DSPACE.
+-- http://flywaydb.org/
+-- ===============================================================
+
+-------------------------------------------------------------
+-- This will create COMMUNITY handle metadata
+-------------------------------------------------------------
+
+insert into metadatavalue (metadata_field_id, text_value, text_lang, place, authority, confidence, dspace_object_id) 
+  select distinct 
+  	T1.metadata_field_id as metadata_field_id, 
+  	concat(T2.handleprefix, h.handle) as text_value,

replies.bodyText: @tdonohue  I followed the mentioned steps, It works. I only had to change double quotes with single quote since both postgres and h2 were failing (double quotes was interpreted as a column name).
replies.author: alemarte

timeline.message:
[CSTPER-221] Script Flyway to populate handle metadata

Sql placeholders replacement.
